questions.text: The given image is the cross-section of the midbrain. A lesion in the area marked with red color will lead to

choices.text: Ipsilateral paralysis of the lower part of the face
Contralateral paralysis of the whole face

questions.solution:
The above image shows the area of midbrain damaged in Weber syndrome. In Weber syndrome, there is involvement of oculomotor nerve leading to ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia.

Weber syndrome:

It is caused by the occlusion of a branch of the posterior cerebral artery that supplies the midbrain, resulting in the necrosis of brain tissue involving the oculomotor nerve and crus cerebri (involving frontopontine, corticospinal and corticonuclear fibers).

There is ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia and contralateral paralysis of the lower part of the face, the tongue, and the arm and leg.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome/Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery

C/L loss of conscious proprioception, C/L hemiplegia, I/L tongue paralysis.

Lateral Medullary syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body, I/L loss of pain/temperature on face, Ataxia, Nystagmus, Vertigo, Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis and loss of gag reflex.

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery

I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out, C/L hemiplegia, C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: The strength of muscle contraction with successive stimuli muscle as recorded by a research student is as shown below. The phenomenon shown in the image is due to?

choices.text: Synthesis of stable troponin C molecules

questions.solution:
Treppe phenomenon shown in the image is due to increased availability of intracellular calcium.

Treppe phenomenon:

  • Changes in muscle strength at the onset of muscle contraction due to repeated stimuliis known as staircase effect or treppe phenomenon.
  • When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, its initial strength of contraction may be as little as one half its strength 10 to 50 muscle twitches later.
  • That is, the strength of contraction increases to a plateau, a phenomenon called the staircase effect, or treppe.
  • It is believed to be caused primarily by increasing calcium ions in the cytosol because of the release of more and more ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum with each successive muscle action potential and failure of the sarcoplasm to recapture the ions immediately.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a single hypo-aesthetic and a hypo-pigmented patch on the lateral aspect of the forearm. Granulomatous inflammation is seen but acid-fast bacilli are not identified. The diagnosis is __________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tuberculoid leprosy.

On microscopic examination, tuberculoid leprosy have granulomatous lesions closely resembling those found in tuberculosis. Because of the strong host defense, bacilli are almost never found, hence the name paucibacillary leprosy.

Leprosy or Hansen disease, is a slowly progressive infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae, mainly affecting the skin and peripheral nerves.

  • Lepromatous leprosy contain large aggregates of lipid-laden macrophages (lepra cells), often filled with masses (“globi”) of acid-fast bacilli -Multibacillary.
  • Borderline leprosy: perineural fibrosis with onion-skin pattern; more the circumscription of the granulomatous response, more the lymphocytes and closer the relationship to nerves
  • Indeterminate leprosy: scanty superficial and deep lymphohistiocytic infiltrate in the dermis
  • Histioid leprosy: spindle-cell proliferation with storiform pattern
  • Lucio phenomenon: leukocytoclastic vasculitis and epidermal infarction

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Ridley Jopling Classification in Leprosy

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Tuberculoid Leprosy (TT) and Lepromatous Leprosy (LL)

questions.text: Identify the virus in the following transmission cycle:
questions.solution:
Transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus is shown above.

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons).  The basic cycles of transmission are:

 (a)Pig → Mosquito  → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

Other options:

Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted by animals to humans. 

Transmission:

  • Unprotected exposure to the secretions from the pigs, or unprotected contact with the tissue of a sick animal.
  • Consumption of fruits or fruit products (such as raw date palm juice) contaminated with urine or saliva from infected fruit bats.
  • Human-to-human transmission through close contact with people's secretions and excretions.

The image depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus.

Ebola virus belongs to the family filoviridae and is transmitted by bats.

  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.

Zika virus is transmitted to humans primarily through the bite of an infected Aedes species mosquito (Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus).

  • Anyone who lives in or travels to a region with risk of Zika infection, and has not already been infected with Zika virus can get it from mosquito bites. Once a person has been infected, they are likely to be protected from future infections
  • A pregnant woman can pass Zika virus to her fetus during pregnancy. Zika is a cause of microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects. Zika virus has also been found in breast milk. Possible Zika virus infections have been identified in breastfeeding babies, but Zika virus transmission through breast milk has not been confirmed.
  • Zika can be passed through sexual intercourse, even if the infected person does not have symptoms at the time.
  • To date, there have not been any confirmed blood transfusion transmission cases in the United States. There are reports of laboratory acquired Zika virus infections, although the route of transmission was not clearly established in all cases

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the drug delivery system shown in the image below?

choices.text: Ensures continuous constant absorption of the drug till patch is applied
Drug absorption versus time graph has more peaks compared to an oral drug
Ensures hundred percent bioavailability of the drug
Absorption is independent of the surface area over which it is applied

questions.solution:
The image shows a transdermal patch for transdermal drug delivery. It ensures continuous constant absorption of the drug.

Transdermal patches like these are available for 

  • Nicotine for smoking cessation
  • Oestradiol for HRT
  • GTN for angina
  • Fentanyl for analgesia

The site of the application of the transdermal patches may affect the systemic drug concentration as absorption through dermal circulation is a bit different over different areas of skin. For example, absorption from nicotine patches applied over the upper arm and back were higher compared to when it was applied to the abdomen.

The below diagram explains the parts of a transdermal patch.

Other options:

  • Drug absorption versus time graph has fewer peaks compared to an oral drug and hence fewer toxicities.

 

  • A hundred percent bioavailability is possible only with Intravenous administration

 

  • The absorption of the drug is dependent on the surface area on which the transdermal patch is applied and the lipid solubility of the drug.

questions.text: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on cold water irrigation?

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.solution:
In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

Fitzgerald–Hallpike test/bithermal caloric test:

  • In this test, the patient lies supine with head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical.
  • Ears are irrigated for 40 seconds alternatively with water at 30°C and at 44°C (i.e., 7° below and above normal body temperature) and eyes are observed for the appearance of nystagmus till its endpoint.
  • Time taken from the start of irrigation to the end point of nystagmus is recorded and charted on a calorigram.
  • If no nystagmus is elicited from any ear, the test is repeated with water at 20°C for 4 min before labeling the labyrinth dead.
  • A gap of 5 min should be allowed between two ears.

 

Cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side (remember mnemonic COWS: cold–opposite, warm–same).

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented to the Opd with complaints of double vision on looking left side. The below given image show the patient when asked to look towards the left side. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the left eye of the patient has limitation of movement laterally. From the given clinical features and image, the diagnosis is sixth cranial nerve palsy.

The sixth cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus. In case of lateral rectus palsy,

  • There is a convergent squint with limitation of movement outwards, and the face is turned towards the paralysed side
  • Homonymous diplopia occurs on looking to the paralysed side
  • The images are on the same level and erect, becoming more separated on looking more towards the paralysed side.

WHO has completed a project known as MONICA, it is related to cardiovascular diseases. It stands for the multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases. It was done to study the reasons for the changes in the trends of cardiovascular diseases in different countries. 26 countries were participating in this project, which was planned to continue for a 10 year period ending in 1994.

This project specifically focussed on trends in event rates for coronary heart attacks and strokes, and on trends in cardiovascular risk factors ( blood pressure, cigarette smoking and serum cholesterol) in men and women aged 25-64 in the same defined communities.

The WHO MONICA project has without any doubt significantly contributed to global prevention efforts. The MONICA methodology is increasingly used as a measurement tool for cardiovascular and non-communicable disease prevention and control programs.

questions.text: Moderate ARDS (as defined by Berlin definition) is characterized by all, except _______
questions.solution:
Moderate ARDS (as per the Berlin definition) is characterized by all, except PaO2/FiO2 200 - 300mmHg.

Moderate ARDS is characterized by PaO2/FiO2: 101 - 200 mmHg

Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition: The Berlin definition requires each of the following criteria be present to diagnose ARDS:

  1. Onset- Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun within one week of a known clinical insult
  2. Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: must be present on a chest X-ray image or CT scan
  3. Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause.
  4. Impairment of oxygenation must be present: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS:

 

Severity

PaO2/FiO2

On ventilator settings that

include PEEP ≥5 cm H2O.

Mild

 

 > 200 mmHg but ≤ 300 mmHg

Moderate

 > 100 mmHg but ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe ≤ 100 mmHg

 

Note: American-European Consensus Conference (AECC) classification of ARDS is no longer used.

 

Image: Alveolar/interstitial infiltrates in ARDS patient

questions.text: A 20 yr old male was brought to casualty in unconscious state after a head injury.What is the name of the sign seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The image is of battle sign i.e. a skull base fracture associated with bruising over mastoid process.

Middle Cranial Fossa Fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

Anterior Cranial Fossa Fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Carotico-cavernous fistula
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

Duret hemorrhages are delayed, secondary brainstem hemorrhages. They occur in craniocerebral trauma victims with rapidly evolving descending transtentorial herniation. They are typically located in the ventral and paramedian aspects of the upper brainstem.

Kernohan phenomenon is an imaging finding resulting from extensive midline shift due to mass effect, resulting in indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. 

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: You are monitoring uterine contractions in a primigravida at 38 weeks in labor.  You find that the uterine contractions are uncoordinated and frequency is about 6 contractions in 10 minutes. Which of the following is not true regarding your finding?

choices.text: It is common in nulliparous labour
Management includes wait and watch policy

questions.solution:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of uterine tachysystole and oxytocin administration is not beneficial in tachysystole (Hypertonic uterine dysfunction.)

Tachysystole (Hypertonic uterine dysfunction)

  • The uterine contractions are incoordinated and increased in frequency (>5 contractions in 10 minutes) without rest in between and also increase in the baseline tone.
  • It is associated with late active phase dysfunction (not latent). i.e. when cervix is almost 7 cm dilated.
  • The most common cause is occipito posterior. Hence, wait and watch policy is adopted.
  • More common in nulliparous females
  • Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of uterus. Hence not recommended.

Hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

  • The uterine contractions are inadequate.
  • It is associated with early active phase.
  • More common in nulliparous females.

questions.text: A premature newborn infant is found to have a systolic murmur with late accentuation over the left infraclavicular area. This is due to the patency of ________
questions.solution:
A systolic murmur with late accentuation/ continuous murmur heard in premature infants is usually due to patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

In fetal life, the patency of ductus arteriosus is maintained by low oxygen tension and endogenously produced prostaglandins. In a full-term neonate, oxygen is the most important factor controlling the duct closure. In normal neonates, functionally ductal closure completes by 10-15 hours after birth. However, in premature infants, patent ductus arteriosus is common especially with the context of respiratory distress syndrome.

Note:

Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is more common in premature infants.

Other options:

  • VSD: Loud, harsh or blowing holo-systolic murmur present over the left sternal border, frequently accompanied by thrill.
  • PFO/ASD: Characteristic is the wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound. An ejection systolic murmur could be heard over the left sternal border.

questions.text: A 24-yr-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
An excess desire for sexual intercourse in males is called satyriasis. 

Satyriasis is also known as Don Juanism. In some men, sexual activity is a means to mask their deep feelings of inferiority. Some have unconscious homosexual impulses, which they deny by compulsive sexual contact with women. Many of them are no longer interested in the women after sex.

Other options

  • Nymphomania: An excess desire for sexual intercourse in females
  • Frotteurism: Sexual gratification achieved by touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person.
  • Masochism: The tendency to derive sexual gratification from one's own pain or humiliation.

Note: Don Juanism represents hypersexuality in males.

questions.text: Which of the following is a low potency local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
The potency of procaine is low.

Potency depends on hydrophobicity. Hydrophobicity can be increased by the addition of alkyl groups to the molecule.

Tetracaine, bupivacaine, etidocaine are highly potent LA.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Local Anesthetics based on the Potency

Low Potency

Procaine

Intermediate Potency

Mepivacaine

Prilocaine

Chloroprocaine

Lidocaine

High Potency

Tetracaine

Bupivacaine

Etidocaine

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine

Naturally occurring

Vasoconstrictor

1st Local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine

Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine

Safest

Causes maximum methemoglobinemia

Suitable for Bier’s IV block

EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

Long acting

Most cardiotoxic

Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia

Toxicity  is treated with amiodarone, bretyllium(for VT), vasopressors e.g. epinephrine, vasopressin (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia

1st synthetic LA

Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: Deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is seen in:
questions.solution:
Deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is seen in pneumothorax.

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally producing the deep sulcus sign.

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When this collection of gas is constantly enlarging with resulting compression of mediastinal structures it can be life-threatening and is known as a tension pneumothorax.

The best X-ray view to diagnose pneumothorax is a PA view in full expiration.

Types of pneumothorax:

  • Primary spontaneous: No underlying lung disease
  • Secondary spontaneous: Underlying lung disease is present
  • Iatrogenic/traumatic  

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • The deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is an indication of a pneumothorax. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign.

AP view plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax in a patient with bilateral pneumonia. There is an increase of transradiancy at the left lung base and the costophrenic sulcus laterally is more pronounced (‘deep sulcus sign’).
